questions.text: A 55-year-old male presented with intermittent leg swelling for the past two weeks. He has a history of hypertension and diabetes for eight years. Examination and investigations revealed findings consistent with nephrotic syndrome. Which of the following is not a diagnostic characteristic of nephrotic syndrome?
questions.explanation:
Diagnostic criteria for Nephrotic syndrome

Essential findings
  • Proteinuria of > 3.5 g/day (Option A)
  • Urine PCR > 2g protein/g of creatinine
  • Hypoalbuminemia - serum Albumin < 2.5 gm% (Option C)
  • Oedema due to reduced oncotic pressure

Other findings
  • Hypercholesterolemia,
  • Lipiduria (Option B)

Urine microscopy: Oval fat bodies/Maltese cross bodies

  • Low eGFR
  • Hypercoagulability

Primary causes

Secondary causes
  • Minimal change disease (Most common in children)
  • Focal Segmental Glomerulosclerosis (Most common in adults)
  • Membranous Glomerulosclerosis (common in older populations)
  • IgA nephropathy (rare)
  • Amyloidosis
  • Diabetic nephropathy (Most common)
  • Membranoproliferative Glomerulonephritis, like lupus nephritis
  • HIV and COVID-19

questions.text: A 65-year-old male presents with complaints of bilateral swelling of the legs and has a history of nephrotic syndrome. Which of the following pathophysiological changes is primarily responsible for the fluid retention in his condition?
questions.explanation:
Nephrotic Syndrome  
Clinical manifestations Pathophysiology
Proteinuria The damage to the glomerular filtration barrier leads to increased permeability to proteins. (Option B)
Odema

Hypoalbuminemia


 
  • Due to urinary loss of albumin being more than its synthesis by the liver.
  • Muehrcke's lines (linear white lines in the nail bed seen in hypoalbuminemia)
Hyperlipidemia

Xanthoma and xanthelasma can be appreciated.
Hypercoagulability

This can be due to factors like:

  • Due to the loss of anticoagulant proteins like Protein C/ Protein S/ Antithrombin III
  • Ferritin deficiency
  • History of factor V Leiden mutation
  • Increased production of procoagulant factors by the liver.
Infections Loss of immunoglobulins in urine causes hypogammaglobulinemia, increasing susceptibility to infections.

questions.text: A 34-year-old woman presents with signs of nephrotic syndrome and has a renal biopsy that confirms Focal Segmental Glomerulosclerosis (FSGS). She has no significant medical history and no history of drug use. Which of the following statements are true regarding this condition? Urine analysis shows nephrotic proteinuria and hematuria. Urine PCR is < 2 Podocyte foot process effacement is seen in electron microscopy Metolazone is contraindicated for refractory edema. More common in African-descent
questions.explanation:
Focal Segmental Glomerulosclerosis  

Pathogenesis

(In primary condition)


 

Podocyte injury ➜ Podocytopenia ➜ Synechiae formation between the GBM & parietal epithelial cells ➜ Glomerulosclerosis.
Clinical manifestation
  • Microscopic hematuria
  • Nephrotic-range proteinuria (often significant) (Statement 1)
  • Hypertension
  • Edema, starting with periorbital swelling
  • Declining eGFR over time
More common in individuals of African-American descent (Statement 5)
Investigations
  • Kidney function test: Reduced eGFR
  • Urine microscopy: Shows hematuria
  • Urine PCR: >2 g/g proteinuria
  • Biopsy (USG-guided) Findings: (Diagnostic)
    • Perihilar sclerosis with hyalinosis
    • Hyalinosis and adherence lesion between tuft and Bowman’s capsule
    • Sclerosing tip forming adherence to tubular pole
  • Electron microscopy:
Podocyte foot process shows eﬀacement (Statement 3)
Treatment
  • For Primary FSGS:
  • Proteinuria: Steroids & Cyclosporin can help in remission for people responding to steroids.
  • HTN: ARB/ACEi
  • Edema: Thiazide diuretics
  •  
  • Refractory edema: Metolazone + Furosemide (Statement 4)
    • Spironolactone can be initiated after the edema subsides.
  • Low salt diet
  • For Secondary FSGS, management is based on the cause of the condition.

questions.text: A 30-year-old male visits the outpatient clinic with a 2-month history of worsening leg swelling and increased fatigue. He notes that his urine has been foamy for several weeks. On examination, he displays bilateral lower extremity edema and hypertension. A renal biopsy reveals focal segmental glomerulosclerosis (FSGS). Which of the following is not a cause of primary FSGS?
questions.explanation:
Focal Segmental Glomerulosclerosis (FSGS)

Category

Primary FSGS

Secondary FSGS

Causes
  • Mostly Idiopathic
  • Can be due to mutations in
    • APOL 1,
    • TRPC6 (Autosomal dominant)
    • Podocin (autosomal recessive)
  • Sickle cell anemia
  • HIV
  • HBV
  • Human parvovirus B19
  • CMV
  • EBV
  • Reflux nephropathy
  • Hypertensive nephrosclerosis
  • Alport syndrome
  • Drugs like
    • INF α
    • Heroin
    • Pamidronate
    • Lithium
    • Tyrosine kinase inhibitors.

Presentation

Commonly as Nephrotic syndrome

Mostly asymptomatic can present with nephrotic range proteinuria but not the syndrome

Immunofluorescence

Presence of IgM + C3

Minimal to no change

Morphological Variants of FSGS
Classical variant
  • Most common
  • Presence of focal and segmental IgM & C3
  • Podocyte foot process effacement.
Tip variant
  • Presence of at least one segmental lesion involving the tip.
  • Tip lesions can be cellular or sclerosing.
Perihilar variant
  • Presence of at least one glomerular perihilar hyalinosis
  • Exclude the other types.
Cellular variant

Occluding segmental endocapillary hypercellularity in at least 1 of the glomerulus.
Collapsing variant
  • Collapsed glomeruli.
  • Hyperplasia and hypertrophy of podocytes (pseudo-crescent)
  • Microcysts within dilated tubules
  • Electron microscopy: Interferon footprints
  • This has the worst prognosis and is commonly seen with HIV, pamidronate, and parvovirus infection.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man presents with worsening leg and abdominal swelling, frothy urine, and weight gain over two months. Examination shows significant edema and HTN. Lab tests indicate nephrotic range proteinuria and a renal biopsy reveals thickened glomerular capillary walls with subepithelial immune complex deposition. Which antibodies are most commonly associated with the primary form of this condition?
questions.explanation:
Glomerulonephropathy

Primary causes

Secondary causes
  • PLA2R antibodies (seen in 70%)
  • Anti - thrombospondin 7a ( 3 - 10 %)
  • Infections: Syphilis, malaria, schistosomiasis, leprosy, filariasis, hepatitis B and C .
    • Anti-HBc IgM antibodies (Option C) are indicative of recent hepatitis B infection, specifically targeting the hepatitis B core antigen.
  • Autoimmune conditions:
  • Rheumatoid arthritis (Anti-CCP antibodies) (Option A)
  • Primary biliary cirrhosis
  • Myasthenia gravis
  • Hashimoto's thyroiditis
  • SLE (Anti-Smith antibodies) (Option B)
  • Cancer: Lymphoma, leukemia, and other organ carcinomas (GI, prostate, breast, lung, bladder)
  • Drugs: Gold, mercury, d-penicillamine, NSAIDs, probenecid, captopril.
  • Other systemic conditions: Fanconi’s syndrome, Guillain-Barré Syndrome (GBS), sickle cell anemia, diabetes.

questions.text: A newborn is diagnosed with congenital nephrotic syndrome presenting with significant edema, low serum albumin, and a history of repeated infections. Which of the following is a common genetic mutation associated with this condition?

A 3-year-old boy presents with periorbital oedema and leg swelling that began a week ago. Laboratory tests reveal 4+ proteinuria and low serum albumin. Blood urea nitrogen (BUN) and creatinine levels are normal. Light microscopy of a renal biopsy reveals no glomerular lesions. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A 7-year-old boy with nephrotic syndrome has experienced multiple relapses over the past year. He responds well to treatment with prednisolone, but his symptoms recur shortly after tapering the medication. According to the clinical definition, what qualifies a patient as having frequent relapses of nephrotic syndrome?

options.label: B
options.text: Three or more relapses in any 12 months

options.label: C
options.text: Three or more relapses within a year after stopping treatment

options.label: D
options.text: Two relapses on a spacing of 6 months

questions.correct_answer: B. Three or more relapses in any 12 months
questions.explanation:
Feature

Steroid-Responsive Nephrotic Syndrome

Steroid-Resistant Nephrotic Syndrome

Definition

Nephrotic syndrome that responds well to corticosteroid treatment.

Nephrotic syndrome that does not improve despite adequate corticosteroid treatment (e.g., prednisolone at 2 mg/kg/day for 6 weeks).

Types:

  • Initial Steroid Resistance: Lack of response from the onset.
  • Late Steroid Resistance: Resistance develops after initial response.

Common Type

Minimal Change Nephrotic Syndrome (MCNS) accounts for about 80% of cases in children.

It is often associated with Focal Segmental Glomerulosclerosis (FSGS) or genetic mutations affecting podocytes.

Diagnosis

Diagnosed without kidney biopsy; characterised by heavy proteinuria, low serum albumin, and no significant glomerular damage.

Further investigation (e.g., kidney biopsy) is required to determine the underlying cause.

Management

Responds to high-dose corticosteroids (e.g., prednisolone), leading to remission of proteinuria and oedema within 10-14 days.

Treatment may include immunosuppressive agents, calcineurin inhibitors, or other therapies, as corticosteroids are often ineffective.

questions.text: A 10-year-old girl presents to the emergency department with complaints of dark, "cola-colored" urine, swelling of her legs, and a headache. Her blood pressure is 150/90 mmHg, and urinalysis reveals hematuria, red blood cell casts, and mild proteinuria. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Features

Nephritic Syndrome

Nephrotic Syndrome

Pathophysiology

Glomerular inflammation leading to GBM damage

Podocyte damage resulting in impaired charge barrier.

Manifestations
  • Hematuria (dysmorphic RBCs)
  • RBC casts
  • Oliguria
  • Hypertension
  • Massive proteinuria
  • Edema
  • Hypoalbuminemia

Urine Findings
  • Hematuria
  • RBC casts
  • Mild proteinuria
  • Frothy urine with fatty casts
  • Massive proteinuria

Proteinuria

Subnephrotic range (< 3.5 g/day)

Massive (> 3.5 g/day) proteinuria

Edema

Mild or absent

Severe edema, especially in the periorbital region, legs, and abdomen

Blood Pressure

Often elevated (d/t renin release)

May or may not be elevated

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy is brought to the pediatric clinic by his mother, who reports he has felt unwell for the past week. He had a sore throat, cough, and fever 10 days ago and now has swelling around his eyes and legs. His urine sample looks dark (shown below). What parameters are commonly seen in this condition?
questions.explanation:
Post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis (PSGN)
Cause Group A β-Hemolytic streptococci
Pathogenesis

Immune-complex mediated (Type III hypersensitivity reaction)
Clinical manifestations
  • It is more common in children and young adults.
  • History of impetigo (2-6 weeks) or pharyngitis (1-3 weeks).
  • Pulmonary oedema (shortness of breath, cough, chest pain)
  • Periorbital and pedal oedema
  • Hypertensive encephalopathy:
    • Abrupt rise in BP
    • Headache
    • Loss of consciousness
  • Features of uremia include fatigue, weakness, confusion, swelling over body parts, shortness of breath, abnormal urine output, nausea, and vomiting.
Test for antibodies
  • Anti- DNAse
  • Anti-Hyaluronidase
  • ASO (antistreptolysin O) titer
Lab findings

Urine analysis: Red-colored urine, which turns dark (cola-colored) on standing (hematuria).

  • Raised values of renal function test (serum creatinine, urea, etc). (Option A)
  • Raised serum potassium (Option C)
  • Low serum levels of C3, IgG & CH50 (Option D)

Normal serum C4 level. (Option B)
Pathological findings

Gross findings: Flea-bitten appearance of kidneys

Light microscopy: Hypercellular glomeruli (increased number of neutrophils, macrophages, endothelial and mesangial cells).

Electron microscopy: Subepithelial humps (due to immune complex deposition)

Immunofluorescence study: A starry-sky appearance (Granular) is observed (due to immune complex deposition).
Management
  • Self-limiting disorder
  • Conservative and supportive management involves:
    • HTN crisis: Labetalol (IV), sodium nitroprusside
    • Pulmonary edema: Furosemide
    • Antibiotics (Benzathine penicillin)
    • Dialysis if needed

questions.text: A 12-year-old boy is brought to the pediatric clinic by his mother, who reports episodes of blood in his urine starting two days after a common cold, along with occasional abdominal pain. The child is vitally stable. Investigations show hematuria with normal kidney function tests and C3 levels. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Berger's disease (IgA nephropathy)  
Pathophysiology
Clinical features
  • Incidental finding
  • Macroscopic hematuria (recurrent) following an upper respiratory infection (URTI)
  • Asymptomatic microscopic hematuria (persistent)
  • If this patient develops an upper respiratory tract infection (URTI), microscopic hematuria can progress to macroscopic (gross) hematuria within 48 hours.
  • Normal blood pressure
  • Normal urine output
Lab findings
  • Normal values of renal function test (serum creatinine, serum urea, etc.)
  • Normal urine output
  • Normal serum C3 level
Pathological findings

Light microscopy: Mesangial proliferation.

Immunofluorescent microscopy: Mesangial deposition of IgA.
Management
  • There is no optimal treatment, but the following drugs are used:
    • ACE-i (angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitors) like captopril and enalapril.
    • Steroids (when the patient has recovered from URTI)
    • Fish oil and tonsillectomy are suggested in studies.

questions.text: A 28-year-old female presents to the emergency department with severe fatigue, leg swelling, and decreased urine output following an upper respiratory infection two weeks ago. Urinalysis shows hematuria and proteinuria. The histopathological findings of renal biopsy are shown below. All of the following are associated with Type II of this condition, except,
questions.explanation:
Type I RPGN

Type II RPGN

Type III RPGN

Cause

Anti-GBM antibody

Immune (antigen-antibody) Complex

Pauci-immune

Associated conditions

Goodpasture syndrome
  • Idiopathic
  • Post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis (PSGN)
  • Lupus nephritis
  • Henoch-Schönlein purpura
  • IgA nephropathy
  • ANCA-associated
  • Idiopathic
  • Granulomatosis with polyangiitis (formerly Wegener granulomatosis)
  • Microscopic polyangiitis
Immunofluorescent microscopy

Linear or ribbon-shaped appearance

It shows a starry sky (lumpy, bumpy, or granular) appearance or garland pattern.
